column7: 10 Twin Pines Lan e, Belmont CA
column8: Come join the opening of my first solo art exhibit at the Twin (S)Pines Art Center and former psychiatric hospital in the beautiful Belmont hills! Powered by @siy_gallery. This is the first (and possibly last) time when all of my original paintings will be exhibited together. They will probably move to Siy Gallery's San Francisco (SOMA) location in March 2024, and then they will begin to travel to Sonoma and progressively take over the world, hopefully! üòâ It will also be my first time presenting my first multi-panel mural, "Holding Space For You". Interesting new semi-secretive art will come to light! My very special guest for this evening will be @neil_murphy_art who deserves a very special neuro-art doctorate for his retina/ serotonin/ dopamine/ optogenetics-themed artwork! üôÇ

column2: Letter Writing and Correspondence hosted by the San Francisco Soidarity Network
column8: Our focus is on prison abolitionist work centered on the struggle of people in prison, jails, and immigrant and juvenile detention centers locally and worldwide. Join us for exchanging letters, starting a pen-pal, or just one-time birthday cards. No commitment necessary We will provide statements from incarcerated individuals, addresses, stamps, and envelopes. We got you, come write with us familia.

column2: Queer and Radical Film Fundraiser for Kyoko! w/ Little Sky, Home, and Criminal Queers
column8: This event is a fundraiser for Kyoko‚Äôs cancer treatment. A beloved queer Japanese American community artist, Kyoko - @jinjabrew, has been diagnosed with Hodgkin‚Äôs Lymphoma cancer. Kyoko can beat this, with the fierce and loving support of community. Join us as we share some independent short films that Kyoko has been a part of, and ensure that Kyoko has access to the healthcare, resources, tools, and love they need during these challenging, extraordinary times.

column2: The Tenderloin Diaries by Carolyn Terry & Todd Pickering
column7: The Tenderloin Museum, 398 Eddy Street, San Francisco CA
column8: Set in the 1990s, The Tenderloin Diaries explores the people and relationships of the TL that straddle both respectable society and its underworld, the everyday and the extraordinary. Conceived to be a serialized television show, The Tenderloin Diaries features an ensemble cast whose archetypal characters‚Äìthe hustler, the pusher, the cabbie, the clerk etc.--outline the distinctive social fabric indicative of the Tenderloin‚Äôs dense, cacophonous, urban environment of SRO hotels, dive bars, and back alleys.The source material for this TV series is drawn from writer Carolyn Terry‚Äôs 30+ years of living in the Tenderloin and keeping journals of all the fantastically kooky denizens of this vibrant, albeit sometimes tragic neighborhood. The cast includes Brian Conway, Trixxie Carr, Jake Eastman, Barbara Godinez, Smelley Kelley, Raya Light, Sue Lyon, Mary Samson and Audra Wolfmann!

column7: Unalome Outfitters, Marina Way South, Richmond, CA, USA  931 Marina Way South #unit a Richmond, CA 94804
column8: Welcome to our annual craft and community event where we find and share our word of the year and make a craft to keep our word close. This year we are partnering with Unalome Outfitters in Richmond (East Bay) so we can use professional equipment to customize a bag with our words. Every year I pick one word - instead of a list of resolutions. I invite you all to come to a NEW makerspace location (Unalome Outfitters) and make a tote bag that showcases your 2024 word of the year.This is a beginner level craft. No experience necessary. Our costs provide materials share and contribute to the costs of our host including the space, snacks, and option for personalized tarot reading.For those who have not participated in this practice: I promise you that it‚Äôll change the way you look at the year ahead.

column2: Dialogue: Crafting Voices with Soham Patel and Tonya M. Foster
column7: Main Libary 100 Larkin Street Afriacan American Center 3rd Floor
column8: Spend an afternoon immersed in poetry and engaging conversation with poets Soham Patel and Tonya M. Foster, moderated by poet Sara Borjas. Listen as the poets share excerpts from their works, followed by a discussion on the evolution and nature of their poetry. Explore how they navigate the creative process, process emotions through poetry and witness the reciprocal transformation between themselves and their work. These three unique voices, each with their own perspective, promise a glimpse into the experience of crafting poetry as women of color.

column2: Mizuko Kuyo Ê∞¥Â≠ê‰æõÈ§ä for Child Martyrs: Clay Workshop & Water Child Ceremony
column7: Artillery AG + Ceramics 2751 Mission Street San Francisco, CA 94110
column8: Mizuko Kuyo is a Japanese ceremony to support the transitioning spirits of babies and the unborn who have died, been killed, aborted, or miscarried. In this three hour gathering, we will gather in embodied ceremony to support the spirits of over 10,000 children and babies who have been killed by Israeli and US-backed genocidal violence in occupied Palestine over the past three months. This is an opportunity to tend to the spirits of this immense wave of new ancestors, many of whom have been denied the dignity of transitioning with traditional rites and protocols.

column8: I am thrilled to announce my curatorial debut with SOCLE DU MONDE, French for ‚Äòbase of the world.‚Äô The show‚Äôs title is inspired by Piero Manzoni‚Äôs bronze sculpture which is a pedestal flipped upside down signifying that the world itself is the art to decipher. This exhibition focuses primarily on sculpture, addressing what I believe is a crucial need in the Bay Area for a spotlight on excellent contemporary sculptural art. I‚Äôve chosen California-based artists who exhibit a mastery of materiality, which is to say that they deeply understand how to build entire worlds within their practices. I hope you‚Äôll join me for a fantastic kickoff on the first Thursday of February so we can answer the question: what holds up this world?

column2: Love Maps, Lisa Silva Gomes at Local Language
column8: Incorporating the printing techniques honed by Local Language, the Love Maps collection utilizes dimension and texture to a surreal effect. Artworks include dream-like visions printed both on and beneath the surface of acrylic; treated as oracle cards offering mysterious guidance. Other surreal sculptural works include an oversized chessboard symbolizing the negotiations made within relationships, a three dimensional puzzle representing the multiple ways our love paths form within our minds, and a heart-shaped treasure box to symbolize the place where we store our dearest memories.

column2: Manifest Differently‚Äù | 38 California visual artists & poets interrogate the history & legacies of Manifest Destiny
column8: üì£ Clarion Alley Mural Project is thrilled to announce its largest exhibition organized in their 32-year history! ‚ÄúManifest Differently‚Äù reflects on a complex web of issues including: inaccurate and outdated perceptions of indigenous peoples; the impact of the U.S. government‚Äôs bureaucracy and policy decisions on indigenous communities in the Americas, Pacific Islands, SWANA nations, and the Global South; post-colonial Latin America‚Äôs ecological crises, regional conflicts, narco-trafficking, and gender struggles; calls for reparations for slavery in the United States; and how local and global communities can move forward from positions of compassion, education, and organizing/action.Poets: Aileen Cassinetto, Avotcja Jiltonilro, Clara Hsu, Dena Rod, E.K. Keith, Fuifuilupe Niumeitolu, Genny Lim, Josiahluis Alderete, Kim Shuck, Lauren Ito, Linda Noel, Lourdes Figueroa, Mahnaz Badihian, Maw Shein Win, Mk Chavez, Stephen Meadows, Tongo Eisen-Martin, Tureeda Mikell, and Voulette Hatta.

column8: MAPP is a familia, a community and a series of arts, music and activist events that has been taking place in the Mission for over 15 years. MAPP is always the first Saturday of the month every two months. MAPP is always free. Mapp will be encompassing anywhere from 3 to 14 venues as well as public spaces, street corners, bart stations, cafes, bars, taquerias, homes all over La Mission. The event features taking common spaces and for one orchestrated beautifully chaotic evening, transforming them into whatever we want: including free live music, Spoken word, Performance art, Film screenings, BBQ's, garage sales, unorthodox conversations and happenings.

column2: Blackout SoundBath: Welcome to the Void of Space
column8: Immersed and wrapped in complete darkness, welcome to the void of space.At the House of Xxhe, our soundbaths are the most unique in the Bay. Laying on the ground under the pitchly lit black-skie of a secret, high ceilinged warehouse in Soma, be bathed in the rolling sounds of warm water, ethereal vocals,  dreamy violins, whisper-speech, and sweet vibration. Alike to a sensory deprivation tank, the ground will shake beneath you as you drift your eyes under the thrawls of a wakeful sleep, recharging and resetting your body for the start of a busy week.

column2: Amirtha Kidambi and Luke Stewart + Beast Nest
column7: The Lab, 2948 16th St, San Francisco CA
column8: In the underexplored combination of bass and voice, Luke Stewart and Amirtha Kidambi mine maximal possibilities, from pure acoustic intimate interactions, to harsh electronic walls of sound. In various configurations of upright bass, amplifier feedback, effects pedals and looping, the duo explores dichotomies, with a side of pristine acoustic duets and another of visceral noise, where the sonic boundaries between the instruments dissolve and obscure. Kidambi employs a distinct vocal effects pedal, meeting Stewart in his amplifier-centered sonic universe. Combining their unique improvised vocabularies which draw from free jazz, noise, rock, Indian music and Black music, their raw chemistry is apparent in their shape-shifting improvisations.

column7: Stanford Health Library 211 Quarry Road, Suite 201 Palo Alto, CA 94304
column8: The Wende Museum is proud to support Stanford School of Medicine in presenting a new, collaborative guest speaker series entitled ‚ÄúArt Across Boundaries" which examines the overlap between visual arts and science and how the two areas can inspire and enrich each other. Join us for a conversation with Robertina ≈†ebjaniƒç. Robertina ≈†ebjaniƒç (Ljubljana) is an artist/researcher whose work explores the biological, chemical, (geo)political and cultural realities of aquatic environments and the impact of humanity on other organisms. Her projects call for the development of empathetic strategies aimed at recognising the other (non-human) species. In her analysis of the Anthropocene and its theoretical framework, the artist uses the terms ‚Äúaquatocene‚Äù and ‚Äúaquaforming‚Äù to refer to the human impact on aquatic environments. Her works received awards and nominations at Prix Ars Electronica, Starts Prize, Falling Walls, RE:Humanism.

column2: Intentional Use of Psychedelics from Antiquity to the Present
column8: ‚ÄãRecently, there has been a resurgence of interest in psychedelics in fields such as neuroscience, therapy, and collective healing. We aim to explore the intentional use of psychedelics in community from antiquity to the present. ‚ÄãInspired by Brian C. Muraresku's groundbreaking book The Immortality Key which shows evidence of LSD-like substances used in ancient Greece and early Christianity for mystical rites of passage, as well as in indigenous cultures (psilocybin mushrooms, Ayahuasca, peyote, Ibogaine, etc), this workshop will explore the value of using psychedelics in group settings for connecting us to deeper questions around the nature of existence. We will explore how such experiences can contribute to both individual and collective healing, foster meaning (in the sense of the philosopher John Vervaeke), and encourage spiritual growth by teaching skillful navigation of ego dissolution for spiritual insight. Our ultimate aim is to bring together like-minded explorers to begin a journey into the inner psyche, both individually and together.‚ÄãYour co-hosts are Nina (currently starting a project about the sociology of psychedelics inspired by her mentor Michael Pollan), Jacob Brawer (neuroscience of psychedelics at Stanford), Gabby White (dreamworker and interpreter of the collective unconscious), and Aaron Meyer (resident experienced psychonaut).

column8: Our vision for this show came about through a shared need for building community.Everyone in the Bay Area feels it; artists and writers especially are no exception to isolation. Even though we create vulnerable works through our art, we sometimes have a hard time connecting with others or finding people that understand the struggle of being an artist. Plus, dating in the Bay Area‚Ä¶ can definitely be a challenge. So, we thought: fuck it.Let‚Äôs create a fun, safe, and sexy community party to bring together the creative bubbles in the Bay and share a special night‚Äî by us, for us.

column2: A Sociological Report Concerning Black on Black Anger in Poetic Form
column8: Artist, poet, and playwright Charles Blackwell returns to the Tenderloin Museum for a performance of his play A Sociological Report Concerning Black on Black Anger in Poetic Form. Known for blurring the lines between mediums, Blackwell contends with this particular facet of systemic racism‚ÄìBlack on Black anger‚Äìthrough his unique vision of hybrid theater and an open-hearted, poetic spiritualism. While the script was written years ago, this current production is a collaboration with the artist Sylvester Guard Jr.--Blackwell‚Äôs impassioned, sensual, jazz-and-blues inflected verse is performed against a set of both artists‚Äô large-scale paintings.

column2: The Urania Trilogy with Tav Falco In Person!!!
column7: 4 Star Theater 2200 Clement StreetSan Francisco, CA, 94121United
column8: Inspired by Urania, the muse of the heavens, her avatar descends from the Bardo plane to earth in the most unlikely guise of Gina Lee, an alienated and disaffected American girl. Disenchanted with hometown strip malls, sleaze bars, and rides along the river-side in her BMW. Impulsively she buys a discount airline ticket in a shopping mall travel agency. Destination: Vienna, the merry/sinister imperial city on the Danube. Gina Lee quickly slips into discreet, yet decadent dalliances at Cafe Central and at the notorious Hotel Orient, where she becomes embroiled in an intrigue to uncover buried Nazi plunder. Her liaison with rakish Karl Heinz Von Riegl builds to a furtive denouement at the Klimt Villa on the alpine shores of Lake Atter. Her fate remains unresolved - until we embark on the newly completed Parts II & III of the troika. The movie then reaches its fatal climax on the grand canal of Venice. This is a black & white filmic poem infused with metaphor and mood, where the past overtakes the present, and the present overtakes the past - now to be seen as one feature film of intrigue, compulsion, and enigma.

column2: Tenants Union, Know your Rights Bootcamp
column8: Tonight! @sanfranciscotenantsunion is in the house for a tenants' rights bootcamp. A volunteer-led tenant advocacy group, SFTU hosts monthly rights "bootcamps" all over the city; this iteration in the heart of the TL includes an educational "know-your-rights" presentation by D5 Supervisor @deanprestond5 , a history of organizing in the Tenderloin by TLM staff, followed by opportunities to ask trained tenant counselors for advice for those facing eviction, unfair rent increases, and landlord negligence.

column2: SEAman By Amica Hunter & Bruce Ryan Costella
column8: The spray of sea salt, the creak of the boards, a flash of lightning, and BOOM! Captain Sea MAN has arrived. Looks like your 30 Minute Scenic Boat Tour just got a little bit more interesting. seaMAN is a dynamic, revenge-fueled sea-venture featuring the horror-comedy hijinks of a weird old captain with an even weirder past. A nautical nightmare of text and physical comedy centered around the outrageous stories and vengeful fantasies of one salty sailor against the entire ocean. Whether it‚Äôs dodging storms, combating scurvy, fighting a seagull, or displeasing a mermaid, Sea MAN seems to find trouble wherever he goes. What HAPPENED to him? Stuck in the past, drowning in the bottle, he is a broken man whose stories can hold you captive even as he steers you further from the safety of the harbor. He lies. He cheats. He‚Äôs a sea MAN. Conceived and performed by award-winning fringe circuit veterans Amica Hunter (ANATOMICA) and Bruce Ryan Costella (Rat Man Happy Place), seaMAN is a one man show‚Ä¶ by two. A sweet & salty theatrical concoction that is as stupid as it is smart. Like The Lighthouse meets Gilligan‚Äôs Island.
Showcasing the works of over 170 Bay Area female-identifying artists, centered specifically around women's rights.

Euclid Manor is pumped to share with you Strange Manners! They bring a soulful, funky, old-school sounds with a powerful new kick. Lorenzo Loera (keys, vocals) and Beaumont Beaullieu (drums) play in the locally-based national touring group The California Honeydrops as their main gig, and they love to bring that retro soul to Strange Manners. Tom Quell (vocals, guitar) aims to bring down the house with his energetic style and angelic voice ‚Äî an alter-ego vibe from his solo project style, which leans toward softer, more acoustic, major-7th-type sounds. Miles Blackwell (bass), Oakland's very own 19-year-old phenom who everyone wants on their gig, is simply one of the funkiest cats you'll ever lay your ears on. Put them all together and you've got Strange Manners. Kinda strange, and kinda cool.

The Indian Classical Sessions are an informal gathering dedicated to sharing the meditative beauty, ecstatic energy, and sheer majesty of South Asian music. Our goal is to connect, build our raga music loving community and share South Asian classical music in an impromptu, casual and attentive setting.This month‚Äôs gathering features:Sasi Madgula carnatic violin George Brooks sax Arjun Ravi Shankar Hindustani Vocal Shreya Adiraju Carnatic Vocal

Whiskerman- is a rock-and-roll overture to our great unraveling. Over the last 7 years the Oakland band has developed an underground reputation for tackling the sublime with their ambitious songwriting, thunderous stage show, and acute lyricism. They have since emerged as an engine of the Bay Area‚Äôs revitalized psychedelic and festival scenes. Frontman Graham Patzner, who will crow like a medicine show preacher, and then coo you into the arms of his lovesick eternity, might be a spitfire protege of the underworld himself, though, through and through he will remind you that there is no rapture without artistry. On the surface this is splendid rock-and-roll, rooted in the classic, psych and glam rock tradition, but the pageantry and chaos of Whiskerman‚Äôs performances will leave you describing an experience more than a sound. The BAND: Graham Patzner (vocals, guitar, violin and piano), Will Lawrence (bass), and Charles Lloyd (guitar and sitar), Dan Schwartz (drums), and Jeremy Lyon (guitar).

column2: Viewing Pleasure, a show by Maria Silk
column8: Viewing Pleasure is a solo performance about chicken, television, sex changes, digestion, consumption, and transformation. How does looking‚Äîand being looked at‚Äîchange who we are? Why did the chicken cross the road? Can subjectivity be reduced to a recipe? When the dumpster of your brain gets too full, who will help you take out the trash? At once humorous and sinister, the piece pairs Butoh- and drag-inspired choreography by Maria Silk with sound design by Jules Litman-Cleper.

This workshop offers participants an opportunity to deepen, reconnect, refresh, and expand your clown world. Paralleling Richard Pochinko‚Äôs methods, the workshop brings participants in touch with the inner energies driving your outwards expressions. Participants will invite their clowns to integrate butoh‚Äôs ‚Äòbeing part of the space‚Äô and ‚Äòbeing danced‚Äô to help create in-depth internal connection that strengthens the clown‚Äôs external clarity and physical expression. Slowing down also gives your clown tools to explore and develop material by decomposing actions to reveal the series of moments and fundamental energies driving them, and offering pathways to embody these energies and play (with) them. Butoh clown is also a great pathway to let go of verbal expression and expand your non-verbal universe.

Get ready to immerse yourself into this vibrant neon scene of the 1990s. Set against a backdrop of spectacular neon footage of Vancouver, Los Angeles, and Las Vegas, this 1997 film is an illuminating exploration into the vibrant history and contemporary use of neon. The movement, power, and raw exuberance of neon is revealed through a fascinating demonstration of how neon is made, a montage of notable neon installations and commentary from a colorful array of neon experts.

Death to Realism is a dance party, a puppet show and a mystical experience. It infuses positive energy and motivational concepts with magical thinking and comedy. It's an existential thought experiment about the ideas that you hold as true can often be holding you back, limiting you and keeping you from letting magic in. It's about breaking down those beliefs and getting outside of the box in your head.

column2: Viewing Pleasure, a show by Maria Silk
column8: Viewing Pleasure is a solo performance about chicken, television, sex changes, digestion, consumption, and transformation. How does looking‚Äîand being looked at‚Äîchange who we are? Why did the chicken cross the road? Can subjectivity be reduced to a recipe? When the dumpster of your brain gets too full, who will help you take out the trash? At once humorous and sinister, the piece pairs Butoh- and drag-inspired choreography by Maria Silk with sound design by Jules Litman-Cleper.

Don‚Äôt miss out on the grand launch of Top2Bottom, the ultimate queer party at Crybaby! This inclusive and safe space is open to all queer individuals and lovers of the queer community. Enjoy a night filled with sexy allure, playful fun, and high-energy dance.   Featuring DJ Assault -  Get ready to experience the legendary DJ Assault, a true pioneer and icon in the realms of ghetto tech and booty bass. With a career spanning decades, DJ Assault has shaped the sound of these genres, delivering infectious beats that have become anthems on dance floors worldwide. Supporting Artists:  DREAMS -  DREAMS, aka Mar Mendoza, is a musician and music producer, as well as a co-founder of El Afters, a queer Latin music and party collective based in Oakland, California. Their sound combines elements of reggaeton, dembow, vogue, and club music.  Del -  Born and bred in the heart of New York City, Del is an exceptional turntablist renowned for remarkable blends and dynamic selections. Known for her technical prowess and love for pushing the envelope, Del made waves by incorporating four decks into her sets. Her performances, seamlessly weaving hip-hop, Drum & Bass, and Happy Hardcore, leave audiences in awe of her unparalleled skills.   Bar Proceeds for a Cause: A percentage of the bar will be donated to the Oakland LGBTQ Community Center, supporting our local queer community üòä  In embracing diversity, we enforce a zero-tolerance policy against homophobia, transphobia, sexism, racism, and any form of discrimination. Top2Bottom is dedicated to fostering an atmosphere of respect, love, and acceptance for everyone who graces our dance floor.

Underbelly is a non-verbal somatic practice (embodied meditation) where we reclaim our slow in a fast and overwhelming world. Our dominant culture survives on speed, which keeps problematic and oppressive structures in place at the devastating cost of our well-being and planetary health. Underbelly is a somatic response to the loss of slowness in an increasingly urgent world drowning in climate collapse, AI threat, technological addiction, diseased capitalism, and polarization, as well as historical nervous system trauma from continuing racism, colonialism, and patriarchy. It's time to dismantle the hurry.

column2: Author: Christopher Pollock, San Francisco's Parks
column7: Noe Valley Public Libary, 451 Jersey Street
column8: Learn about San Francisco's parks with Christopher Pollock, author of San Francisco's Parks. This talk, which includes historical photographs, will reveal the stories of the creation of some of San Francisco's parks. From the town square of Portsmouth Square to the formerly Bayside Gilman Playground, previously known as Gilman Beach, the illustrations show the diverse topography of San Francisco. Many of the parks shown may not be recognizable today as they have morphed over time from open sand lots to sometimes multi-level recreation spots. Other highlights will include the wide variety of activities these places host.

column7: Atrium Theater, 401 Van Ness Avenue - 4th Floor
column8: After two incidents at his public school which culminated in two suspensions, Nya, a public-school teacher, takes her son, Omari, out of the inner-city public school and enrolls him at Fernbrook, a private school far from home. When a third behavioral event happens there, expulsion and possible criminal charges might be next, Nya must confront the decisions and sacrifices she‚Äôs made to ensure Omari‚Äôs success. Written by MacArthur Fellowship recipient (The Genius Award) Dominique Morisseau, herself a former Detroit schoolteacher, Pipeline puts a magnifying glass on the complexities and nuances of Black parenting in the inner-city to the forefront.

column8: KQED culture writer Rae Alexandra chronicles the forgotten stories of women who defied the restrictions of their time in her series Rebel Girls From Bay Area History. We‚Äôll hear their stories in this bingo night, co-hosted by KQED Arts & Culture‚Äôs Senior Associate Editor, Sarah Hotchkiss. TYPE 2 FUN is an original and irreverent standup comedy special that is back for one weekend only, after debuting to sold out audiences in the 2023 San Francisco Fringe Festival.A self-described ‚Äúmental patient with a microphone‚Äù, Barb uses cringe comedy to deliver uncomfortable truths that navigate through the beauty, complexity and frustration of life itself. Living under Capitalism. Living with the Patriarchy. Living as Queer.Barb speaks to the modern disaffected millennial trash, using her acerbic wit to game the capitalist system we are all stuck in. She is a feminist who thinks the Me Too movement failed women because it didn‚Äôt embolden sexuality. And her appearance permits her entry into a gay men's bath house, which she elaborates about in detail. Barb‚Äôs insights are for the disillusioned she‚Äôs, they‚Äôs, and all the bozos in between.

column2: S L O W with Ahran Lee
column8: When was the last time you were able to S L O W down and listen to the wisdom of your body? When was the last time you were able to S L O W down and explore the narrow and deep of your interior life? When was the last time you were able to S L O W down and just simply exist? In this authentic relating space, we‚Äôll explore the intellectual, physical, and emotional spaces of slowness. In the age of hyper-productivity and efficiency, addiction to consumption, and toxic fragmentation of time, let‚Äôs boldly step into radical choice and indulge in the S L O W. Through improvised guided meditations, classic authentic relating games, and a sprinkle of improv play, Ahran will facilitate a S L O W evening as she explores her own resistance to slowness.

column8: For Joseph Kamaru (KMRU) a Nairobi-born Berlin-based sound artist, sound is a sensorial medium through which social, material and conceptual interpretations are manifested in his works. KMRU carries with him a repository of listening experiences from Nairobi and beyond expanding his sonic practices, bringing an awareness of surroundings through creative compositions, installations and performances. He has earned international acclaim from his performances and releases , at the Barbican, Berlin Atonal, Pr√©sences √©lectronique, and releases on Editions Mego, Subtext, Seil Records. KMRU has carved out a serious and definitive space on the list of essential authors in ambient experimental music - one of the most prolific and innovative artists in his field.

While we, as P@lestinians all over the world, experience collective grief, Refugee Eye Gallery returns this year with a special exhibition that both features and is curated and organized by artists from Ghazza. Our goal is to create a space where we can raise our voices with visual stories and memories of a home that is no longer the same.

Crochet Jam, hosted by sculptor Ramekon O'Arwisters, uses the folk-art tradition of crocheting strips of fabric into free-form and organic soft sculptures to foster social interaction, creativity, and liberation. There aren't any rules nor patterns. Crochet Jam is an opportunity for play, experimentation, and for allowing the material to transform naturally without any expectations nor any attempt to control the outcome. Participants become a conduit for the transformation of the material without any resistance, whether they like what they see or not. Participants just crochet and calmly observe without judgment or critique.

The exhibition Mane ‚Äòn Tail honors this intimate kinship that has been developing over thousands of years between our two species. Through painting, sculpture, and black and white photography, this three person exhibition employs whimsy, conceptual rigor, and technical craft to explore the partnership between equine and equestrian. Horses are the most represented animal in prehistoric art. Well before their domestication, we revered them for their grace, strength, beauty and freedom. Carl Gustav Jung considered the horse as one of the archetypes of the mother as it carries its rider. In Celtic and Chinese mythology, they are viewed as a symbol of good luck. In Guinea, the horse‚Äôs tail was used as a peace offering to the Gods to secure a successful harvest. North American Indigenous tribes viewed them as ‚Äúspirit‚Äù brothers. Drawing from history, mythos and psychology, the artworks in Mane ‚Äòn Tail express the iconography of the horse not only as a beast of burden, but each animal as a beautiful sentient being with its own thoughts, fears and capacity to love; drawing parallels between two species with a fate that is eternally interwoven.

column2: Animal prince, King Dream, Sass and Harmony
column7: Rickshaw Stop, 155 Fell St, San Francisco, CA 94102
column8: Duo Animal Prince brings a refreshingly retro vibe to contemporary soul/pop. Their dynamic arrangements, led by vocal, violin, vibraphone, synths, and percussion, are as introspective as they are retrospective. Fae Nageon de Lestang and Grant McLeod matured their sound with playful and emotional dreamscapes while writing and recording inside their geodesic dome home in Northern California. https://www.animalprince.com/ King Dream is a Bay Area rock ‚Äòn‚Äô roll band helmed by Oakland native Jeremy Lyon, a lifelong songwriter and multi-instrumentalist who crafts dive bar anthems with heart, brains and soul. Hard-rocking yet poignant, his music combines a love for American rock masters like Springsteen and Petty with ‚Äò60s West Coast psychedelia and more contemporary torch-bearers like My Morning Jacket and The War on Drugs ‚Äî all brought to life by a band of Northern California‚Äôs most in-demand players. https://www.kingdreamband.com/ Sass N Harmony is a multi-instrumental trio out of Oakland CA, best described as soul folk. The music of Sass N Harmony is imbued with mischief and magic to bring you lyrics immersed in archetypes and folk-tales. https://www.sassnharmony.com/

column2: Antimatter, Laetitia Sonami, Douglas McCausland, Heartworm
column8: Antimatter What is the voltage of static electricity that courses over your skin standing each of five million hairs straight on end? Can the answer be derived quantitatively from the waveforms cascading against malleus, anvil and stapes to trigger follicle surge? Or is math itself lost in the abstraction to qualitative, perceptual, and metaphysical sense? Such shortcuts to madness are best explored through the complexities of minimal materialism, particles of sound as sculpted by Antimatter, the solo project of Xopher  Davidson.https://soundcloud.com/antiphonic-1 Laetitia Sonami Discovery narrows, contours deepen to become edges tipping your balance, opening a course below the beaten path. Tracing arabesques, Laetitia Sonami pilots a bathysphere of fantasmic depth extending her body to entwine, tentacular, across oceans of sound. "In ancient times when we peered endlessly into hazy green screens flickering like glow worms, adding a bit of flesh was irresistible" she recalls. As early as 1991, Sonami would "leave some of the glamour behind" in order to explore "attractive weaknesses...the boundaries of expression, the pushback on one's intent." Thirty years deep, a triangulated ring appeared in her work, the Spring Spyre, like an aperture in her chambered nautilus it reveals darkening depths still to be plumbed. When you find Sonami beginning her set inside the Peacock Lounge, don't bother taking a big breath first, there's plenty down there. https://vimeo.com/75110440 http://sonami.net/ Douglas McCausland Sounding a contrast of extremes using purpose-built interfaces, spatial audio, interactive systems, machine-learning, and hardware-hacking, McCausland finds sound where it first spawns, between nerve roots and bare metal. There's a difference between just burning down conventions and knowing how to build back better from scratch. In the process, organic and synthetic can meld anew, taking shape in real time and real life. McCausland jumped the wall at CCRMA to alight inside the new gleaming eyrie at SF Conservatory of Music teaching courses in the Technology and Applied Composition program. Be there when he swoops on the Peacock Lounge, then keep an eye on his work in the years to come at SFCM. https://ex-log.bandcamp.com/album/entanglement Heartworm Twenty-year veteran of subterranean music, Brandon Yahiro-Taylor, has recorded and performed in a dizzying array of styles, from freeform minimalism to harsh noise to breakcore to experimental metal to indie rock to ambient and musique concrete. On the east coast he founded the seminal net label slum.org before moving to San Francisco in 2003 where he became active with the 5lowershop soundsystem crew, organizing events throughout the bay area. https://soundcloud.com/heartworm

column2: ‚ÄúThe People‚Äôs Palace‚Äù a Site Specific Dance Performance
column8: Performance Every 30 min - The People‚Äôs Palace is an artistic intervention with City Hall‚Äôs Beaux-Arts Roman and Greek iconography. Aerialists and performers will interact with the architecture and large scale projections, transforming these symbols into new, more inclusive narratives that more accurately reflect San Francisco‚Äôs diverse and dynamic cultures and community. Through performance, music, storytelling, and immersive technologies, The People‚Äôs Palace invites the audience to actively engage these new narratives, to see themselves within the broader context of the city, and to appreciate the richness of diverse perspectives.

column2: Get a Grip! A solo clown play
column8: Get a Grip! is about an ex circus performer turned stagehand with high hopes to be the next superstar! Our underdog is preparing for the big show by doing work they always do in the shadows. But there's a big problem: the artists never arrive! Our burnout turned hero struggles to rise to the occasion due to their own battles with addiction. Will our backstage hero rediscover their desire to have a better life and fulfill their dreams once again!?This solo clown show uses physical comedy and circus acts rarely seen in the US such as: plate spinning, jar juggling, 12ft bamboo pole umbrella manipulation. If you don't know what those things are, you better come find out! Be whisked away to a distorted realm of this oddly eccentric "underdog" and their authentic and strange reality!May 10 & 11 at 8pm

Banda Sin Nombre combines folk music from around the world with performance art, drag, and dance. With creative roots in San Francisco‚Äôs Mission District, the band features rich vocal harmonies with acoustic instruments including guitar, fiddle, charango, jarana, cajon, upright bass, and saxophone. The band‚Äôs musical influences range from Peruvian chicha to Catalan rumba and Appalachian old time to Cumbia.

In this workshop, we will explore the physical attributes of your personal clown  characteristics. The class consists of a neutral body exploration and physical movement exercises designed to help the student develop their personal   clown through their own physically natural movements. We look deep within  to discover the masks we wear, then strip them away to the best of our ability  to rediscover our authentic selves. This workshop is intended to challenge the  preconceived notions we have of what makes us funny. Later this year Faeble will leave to tour in Germany, so don't miss your chance to study with this international performer & instructor!

The vocalist, producer and DJ is responsible for worldwide smash 'B.O.T.A (Baddest Of Them All)' ‚Äî the track that soared to Number One and saw her crowned as the first female DJ to top the official charts in 20 years. But it didn't happen out of thin air: Eliza has long been circling London's clubs, festivals and record shops, cultivating invaluable taste as a selector. Now having collected MOBO and Brit nominations, plaques, magazine covers and a world tour, she's straddling both the underground and global superstardom.

Trying to be funny isn‚Äôt very funny. But oh my word is it funny to be authentic. The clown, above all, seeks to be one hundred percent purely, authentically (even overly and embarrassingly) committed to the truth in the moment. And hence, the ha-ha.In this clown workshop, explore how chasing beauty, depth and vulnerability on stage can lead to comedy on a level that hits harder than you could have ever imagined. Find the funny through the not-so-funny and be amazed by the hilarity in being exactly who you are.We will use writing and performance prompts and exercises designed to reveal and break down beliefs about what is and isn‚Äôt funny, what should and shouldn‚Äôt be shown on stage, and what is and isn‚Äôt the fourth wall. The clown doesn‚Äôt adhere to (or even understand) the societal constructs around us, so embodying our clowns gives us permission to dissolve made-up rules and connect with ourselves and the audience to find the ha-ha and boo-hoo in truly profound ways.A safe (but deep) dive into the parts we don‚Äôt want to show, where we can find the power of clowning, guided by Claire Woolner and John Norris (award-winning absurdist comedian/clowns who have earned their accolades by crying on stage so much that the audience laughs and bewildering the audience into fits of snorting hysteria, respectively.) There is no pressure to be, do or make anything funny and no prior clowning experience is required‚Äìwe will just explore the depths and see where they lead. But my gut tells me we‚Äôre gonna find some pretty absurdly hilarious shit.

column2: Inclusive Apparel at Sports Basement Presidio!
column7: 610 Old Mason Street San Francisco, CA 94129
column8: Adaptive apparel expert Tracy Vollbrecht has teamed up with Sports Basement to talk about how mainstream, performance apparel can work for people of all abilities. Join us on May 30th at 6:30pm at the Presidio Sports Basement! Whether you're a wheelchair basketball player, parent of a kid with disabilities, a runner with a prosthetic, or disability advocate, you'll discover garment features to enhance performance and comfort. This event is also a great opportunity to get your voice heard and network with adaptive athletes from around the Bay. If you have specific performance apparel needs or ideas, we want to hear from you! Drinks and snacks and a discount provided by Sports Basement. Please RSVP through Eventbrite. Don't miss this opportunity to learn about inclusive design in sports clothing. See you there!

Join HALA collective and MASGD for a conversation about hope and resistance as we enter Pride Month and witness some of the largest escalations in the genocide against Palestinians, as well as the ongoing genocides in Sudan, Congo, West Papua, Burma, Xinjiang (Uyghur), and many other regions. Amid countless injustices, how we engage and sustain our hope practices is essential. This conversation will center the voices of Black, Indigenous, and Palestinian queer and trans Muslims at the intersection of these forms of violence within and beyond the US empire.

Meet outside the entrance to the Glen Park BART station at 9:30 a.m. Our 10-mile walk combines stretches of the Crosstown and Double Cross Trails, and features many iconic San Francisco landmarks. We start on the Crosstown through Glen Canyon to the ‚ÄúTri-Trail Junction,‚Äù below Twin Peaks where the Crosstown, Double Cross, and Bay Area Ridge Trails meet. There, we hop onto the Double Cross, hike up and over Twin Peaks, and wind our way through Tank Hill, Mt. Olympus, and Buena Vista Park before lunch at Alamo Square. We then head to Nob Hill, Chinatown, and North Beach to descend the Greenwich Steps to Levi‚Äôs Plaza and continue along the Embarcadero to Embarcadero Station for a true BART-to-BART excursion. Expect elevation gain. Dress in layers. Bring water, snacks, and lunch.

Suggest long pants and long-sleeved shirts in case of poison oak, wild blackberry, wind, and fog; walking poles helpful. Route includes Glen Canyon, Twin Peaks, Mt. column8: Visual art show happening in the dog patch, Featuring Artists: AJ Serrano Baylee Lewis Van Ella Rose Avery Char Castagna Malkia Williams Our goal: The ongoing genocide in Palestine prompts us to reflect urgently on ourselves and our communities. Unity is crucial; we cannot afford apathy to divide us during this crisis. This exhibition aims to foster resilience and envision a liberated Palestine through powerful visual art. Artists will present works, both new and existing, that challenge viewers to empathize with one another. Ultimately, the goal is to cultivate compassion and leave folks with the desire to maintain and create community!

column2: Performance: Polar Resoundings by eco-composer Cheryl E. Leonard
column8: Field recordings from Antarctica and the Arctic intertwine with sounds played live on penguin bones, rocks, shells, driftwood, and kelp in a musical performance by Cheryl E. Leonard. Having witnessed firsthand the wonder and beauty of both polar regions, as well as rapid changes to their environments and ecosystems, Leonard presents a suite of compositions about the ends of our Earth. Informed by scientific research, her music showcases unique sounds from ice, wildlife, and weather, and shares stories from the transforming soundscapes of Svalbard and the Antarctic Peninsula.

Andrew Winn is a distinguished leader at the intersection of environmental and criminal justice, currently serving as the Executive Director of the Insight Garden Program. As a formerly incarcerated individual, Andrew brings a unique perspective to his work, emphasizing the transformative power of horticultural therapy within prison settings and holistic reentry support. His commitment extends to higher education, where he played a pivotal role in building and developing the Underground Scholars Initiative at UCLA and Project Rebound at Sacramento State University. Andrew is recognized for his expertise in addressing the challenges faced by individuals impacted by the criminal justice system while actively contributing to meaningful policy changes.

column7: Alchemy Springs ~ 939 Post St SF CA 94019
column8: Have you been curious about Breathwork, Tantra, or both? Would you like to learn more about them and how the divine combination of these 2 sacred practices ROCK your world Perhaps you have deep experience with Breathwork or Tantra and are interested in expanding your experience and seeing where the combo can take you next! Breathwork of various types is central in Tantric practices because it enlivens the body, reveals the spirit‚Ä¶ And basically turns you on, in more ways than one! Human beings are often trying to think their way to enlightenment and a great sensual life, but that's missing the point! We gotta feeeeeel it in our bodies and our souls! Join Alicia & Erwan Davon on July 18th for a revelatory evening where the power of the breath & Tantric practice will not only be understood but practiced, for real!. Whether single or in a relationship, your love life and spiritual life will be even more enhanced!

A raucous, fun-loving, and wild ride through the stages and back streets of the Bay Area, this film tracks one woman‚Äôs journey to find out what sparks life in communities and how music is a powerful entity in days of division and has power in its ability to bring people together. Balkancisco focuses on the idea that there are certain cultural expressions that are so innate to our shared humanity that they cannot be taken away by politics. When a young Turkish immigrant arrives in San Francisco, she finds herself inside an ever-growing Balkan music scene and sets off on a quest to explore how Bay Area has become such a hotbed for Balkan music, how it influenced the local music scene, and how music travels & transcends boundaries and borders. It's important to recognize the ways in which politics can divide us, but also to understand the enduring power of cultural expression and its ability to bring us together.

Subtitle: A surrealist showcase and play. A viscerally intimate and transformative evening of theatrical storytelling, liberation, and empowerment, centering an ethereally surrealist array of literal and metaphorical flowers, alongside queer, BIPOC, and AAPI dance rituals, experimental soundscapes, and earthenware art. Through lenses of myth and metaphor, and boldly embodied pleasure driven alchemy, multi-media floral art seductively unearths and dances with quietly driving underpinnings of a feminine, queer, and black experience. To melodies of intuitive and ancestral movement and psychic luxuriating on mental beds of artful floral arrangements, The Secret Life of Flowers spins healing narrative strings of diverse marginalized voices into deeper environmental power, pleasure, and positive change.

column2: Breathwork & Sound Healing Workshop with Michael Wilson of joyful GRAVITY
column7: Alchemy Springs, 939 Post Street San Francisco, CA 94109
column8: Drop in and rediscover your inner joy through guided active pranayama (breathwork) and sound healing designed and choreographed to take you deep on a personal growth & healing journey with Michael Wilson, ICF-certified Energy & Mindset Coach, trained breathworker & sound healer and enthusiastic joy finder. Guided active pranayama will break up stuck energy in the body, allowing you to drop in below the thinking mind. From there, you're able to let go of mindsets, beliefs and patterns that no longer serve you, making room for a shift to occur so that you can live with peace, freedom and joy. Following active pranayama with sound healing using bowls, chimes & other instruments, restores your nervous system to its resting state, allowing you to leave the workshop feeling calm, clear and connected to your innermost being.

In this Sƒìfari workshop participants will come together to create a stone circle, connect with the element of fire, explore the myths of the body, and plunge into the depths of being. Our intention is anchor the embodiment and convergence of elemental transformation, resurrecting our vitality through ritualized communal immersion. What‚Äôs Included This workshop will include a stone of your choosing, an opening circle, a guided sauna + cold plunge experience, and a closing circle. There will be time for socializing post our Sƒìfari with tea and light snacks.

San Francisco has an impressive array of classic signs that light up the night. Vintage neon is most often found on legacy mom-and-pop businesses: dive bars, bakeries, cafes, cinemas, and restaurants in almost every neighborhood. Highlights of the talk also include the history of neon and local preservation success stories that have given new life and light to some of the City‚Äôs most popular neon landmarks.

column2: Where is the Math in Art? (Roaming Hackerspace Art Walk)
column7: SF Moma 151 3rd St, San Francisco, CA 94103
column8: ‚ÄãTheme: Where is the math in art?SudoRoom and Noisebridge hackerspaces will be converging on the SF Moma during Downtown San Francisco First Thursdays to interweave math, life, art and more! ‚ÄãWe'll begin at the SF Moma the new Kara Walker exhibition Fortuna and the Immortality Garden (Machine) which is in part inspired by science fiction writer Octavia Butler's Parable of the Sower of the philosophy "Earthseed" parable books.The piece is on view at the SF Moma, which is is free for Bay Area residents first Thursday! ‚ÄãWe could start by talking about how mathematical ways of thinking resemble and differ from the "Earthseed" philosophy from those books, which the narrator at one point describes like this: I‚Äôm trying to speak‚Äîto write‚Äîthe truth. I‚Äôm trying to be clear. I‚Äôm not interested in being fancy, or even original. Clarity and truth will be plenty, if I can only achieve them. If it happens that there are other people outside somewhere preaching my truth, I‚Äôll join them. Otherwise, I‚Äôll adapt where I must, take what opportunities I can find or make, hang on, gather students, and teach.

column2: Jejune Institute: ARG Movie Series Pt.1
column8: Curious about Alternate Reality Games? A new renaissance is upon us, co-expanding with the rise of escape rooms, immersive art parties with theatrical experiences, and the many Meow Wolf‚Äôs of the world. One might argue that Fluxus did it first, but Nonchalance really put this type of experience on the modern map in 2008 with the Jejune Institute - an ARG that invited you to an alternate layer of San Francisco for a whopping 4 years of experiences!! Come check out the 90min documentary film that tells the tale. Join us in our theater, enjoy our popcorn, feel free to BYOB drinks / snack / dinner, and stick around to discuss the latest happenings in this field. Just in time for this weekends shenanigans ;) Later parts of this series will include the rest from Nonchalance: In Bright Axiom, Dispatches from Elsewhere, SYGNYL;  the Meow Wolf documentary,  and more

column2: MINDFULNESS & COMPASSION WORKSHOP WITH REA ANTONIOU
column8: Join us for this 90-minute class where you'll bask in the warmth of mindfulness and compassion. This workshop will provide simple tools for mindfully responding in a kind, compassionate manner whenever we are experiencing difficult emotions. Through meditation and experiential exercises, you will have the chance to cultivate skills to help bring self-compassion into your daily life. You will get a glimpse of how to stop being so hard on yourself; handle difficult emotions with greater ease; and motivate yourself with kindness rather than criticism. We hope you will join us!

Like the Sun of the mornings, we are racing once again, to start preparing for a new cycle of the Mission arts and performance project. Please join us on Thursday, August 15 from 7 to 10 PM at Pathos on Harrison. (2754 Harrison St).

Spearheaded by the dynamic Mariam Diakite‚Äîknown for her raw, hypnotic vocals and poetic Bambara lyrics‚ÄîOrchestra Gold pays homage to Malian musical traditions while crafting a fierce new sound with heavy swinging rhythms, a funky fresh brass section, and cosmic guitar licks. column2: Ana Maria Caballero - Beyond the Page
column7: Grey Area 2665 Mission St San Francisco
column8: Ana will share her new poetry collection, "Mammal," exploring the raw realities of motherhood. She‚Äôll also discuss how poetry can be expanded with the use of digital technology.

This exhibition assembles a collection of works that illuminate moments of care, regeneration, and solidarity. The selection of pieces explores questions such as: Who or what heals and nurtures you? What does self-care look like? What does mutual care look like? What gives you the strength to get back up? What do you protect and hold close? How does strength in a community take shape, grow, and evolve? Through images and artwork, the exhibition aims to highlight the regenerative practices and reciprocal relationships that fuel positive narratives of compassion for the self and the wider community.

column2: A night of live Greek and Persian music with rose cacao ceremony
column8: A few years ago when the pandemic finally started to wind down, and people were dancing together again. I had a pleasure of hearing a few amazing musicians live at Alembic in Berkley. I instantly fell in love with the strings of sitar, tabla clicks, flute winds, and beautiful soul awakening vocals - experiences I had only encountered online before. And this is how I met Maz and Alexander, and I have remained a huge fan of their devotional music ever since, only hoping one day to co - create an intimate evening filled with incredible¬†¬†enriching tunes and devotion. To honor the historical and literal wealth of Persia and Greece, we will start with abundance flow rose cacao ceremony with spices. Expanding my abundance mindset and getting codes downloads at the top mt. Shasta, with the permission and container from Source we will go into meditation to open our hearts, heal our ability to receive what we desire - be it beautiful relationships, fulfilling careers, health, or adventures in distant lands. When we pray and meditate collectively, our energies amplify, accelerating our healing and expansion. The second part of the evening will feature one of the most beautiful and captivating musical performances of your life. We look forward to seeing you on August 21st at 7:30 PM at The Center SF, located in the heart of San Francisco, one of the most cherished cities in the world, within its most beloved Painted Ladies neighborhood

column2: SHACK15 Live: Dance I/O - A Night of Embodied Experiments Exploring Art, Dance, and Technology with Kinetech Arts
column7: 2nd floor of the Ferry Building, SF
column8: Join us for an evening of creative expression and hands-on exploration! We're bringing together a diverse group of artists to share their work and research process through a series of mini-performances, each followed by conversations with the creators.Get ready to be immersed in a world where art, dance, and technology converge. But you won‚Äôt just sit back and be art-ed at ‚Äî we're inviting you to actually play with the tools and setups that power these embodied experiments. From electromyography sensors to motion capture cameras and fractal machine painting, you'll have the chance to interact with the technologies that are shaping the future of art and dance. Love tech? This is for you. Enthusiastic about art? Come on by. Both? Bingo. Neither ‚Äî come anyway. Connect with our community, ask questions, share your thoughts, and discover a new spark.

column2: Awakening Sacred Sensuality- a Daylong Tantra Workshop for singles & couples
column7: The Center SF- 548 Fillmore St @ Oak St
column8: What better way to spend a Saturday than embarking on a beautiful adventure of pleasure, connection, and deep exploration? Join Alicia & Erwan Davon of The Davon Method at the beautiful Center SF for Awakening Sacred Sensuality, a unique daylong Tantra workshop designed for singles and couples ready to unlock their inner bliss! Led by both Alicia & Erwan Davon, longtime Relationship & Tantra teachers, this isn't your average "sit and listen" event. At Awakening Sacred Sensuality, we'll immerse ourselves in a variety of interactive exercises, connective touch, and deep meditations, igniting your senses and awakening your spiritual and sensual energy. Whether you attend solo or with your partner, prepare for an unforgettable day filled with pleasure, sensuality, and deep connection. Join us on this electrifying journey into the world of Tantra and discover the ecstasy that awaits you! This in-person event is perfect for couples looking to enhance their connection and for singles seeking to meet like-minded individuals. It's a fun, enlivening experience that empowers you to take control of your love life, bringing presence, awareness, and skill to this vital area of life.Our daylong workshop offers a unique blend of fun and depth, leaving you more connected with your body, heart, and spirit than when you arrived. You'll depart with safe and easy-to-implement skills and practices, suitable for solo exploration or sharing with a partner. Don't miss out on this transformative experience at Awakening Sacred Sensuality!

column2: Unlock the Mystery of Irresistible Attraction for singles & couples
column7: The Davon Method Loft Space-Harrison @ 21st St in SF
column8: Get Ready to Spark Attraction!We all have a sense that that deep down, we have the rizz, we have the charm, we have the za za zou! Accessing it and expressing it‚Ä¶.that‚Äôs another story. Sometimes we are shy about it, sometimes we are scared of rejection, sometimes it has just been awhile and we need a little juicing up-! Join us for a fabulous journey to unlock the secrets of irresistible attraction! Whether you're single and ready to mingle or a couple looking to reignite the flame, this event is for you! Discover the hidden keys to: Radiate confidence and charm Ignite passion and desire in your current relationship or in a potential new one Build and maintain relationships that have staying power‚Ä¶beyond the honeymoon phase Through a presentation of cutting-edge material on modern day attraction, interactive exercises, & a personal Q&A session, you'll experience more power, skill and excitement about the whole realm of dating, relationship and romance! Following the workshop, we will transition into unstructured social time with drinks and snacks so you can enjoy connecting with the other participants and connecting with Alicia & Erwan!

column2: The Bluebird: Part of Flop Fest at Church of Clown

column8: Take flight with physical theater performance: The Bluebird, a wordless & bittersweet journey of dreams and dreamers that invites the audiences to engage with themes of identity, exclusion, and resilience. This production is inspired by Charles Bukowski's evocative poem The Bluebird, Basishvili's own immigration story, and the experiences of countless others who have left their homes for other lands. It poses questions about society's response to the aspirations of newcomers who tenuously hold onto hope, even when their dreams feel unattainable. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a bluebird in my heart that wants to get out,‚Äù opens the first line of Bukowski‚Äôs poem, ‚Äú‚Ä¶I only let him out at night sometimes, when everybody‚Äôs asleep.‚Äù

column2: Portrait XO, MSHR, and Douglas McCausland ‚Äî Gray Area Festival 2024 Performance

Douglas McCausland opens with a visceral and often chaotic set that explores the extremes of sound, technology, and the digital medium.

‚ÄãThis month's MusicLuck is a super special one: Flower Piano at Golden Gate Park! It's fairly different than our usual event, so please read on for all the details. MusicLuck is a potluck for songs. We're an intentionally amateur sing-along jam. üå∫üéπ Setting and theme: Flower Piano This is an extra special MusicLuck because it takes place in public in the SF Botanical Garden. For 10 magical days, the city places 12 pianos around the garden, and anyone is welcome to play them. We'll be bringing MusicLuck to the event for the fourth(!) year in a row. We invite you to join us in wearing florals üíêüå∏üå∑üéüÔ∏è Tickets We won't be selling tickets for this one and don't have a cap, everyone is welcome! Admission to the garden is free for SF residents but $18 otherwise. Tickets are available at the door. You can find all the info about the garden and Flower Piano here.üìçHow to find us We'll scope out pianos a few days before and email out which one we're aiming for. If we need to move to a different piano for unforeseen reasons, we'll send an update email out to everyone registered.‚è∞ Our timing The garden stays open until 7:00, but they technically close the pianos at 6:00 pm. In the past we've had luck staying a bit longer, but will most likely have to wrap up our playing by 6:30. Continuing to hang out until 7:00 is most welcome.üéí To bring (it's a different list for this one, so please do read)üì±Fully charged phones and iPads to pull up lyrics and chords - we won't be projecting for this one as we'll be outside. Also, if your instrument requires both hands, you might bring a stand for your phone/iPad üß∫ A picnic spread and snacks to share - we won't be providing any food since this is a more public even‚Äã‚Äãü™ë Picnic blankets, a lawn chair if you want one, anything else you need to be comfortable at an outdoor event üéª Any instruments you'd like to play! Looking forward to singing with you! üíñ üéº

column2: Nerd Nite SF#146: Psychedelic Science, Geysers, & the New Science of Learning
column8: ‚ÄúPsychedelics & Science - A Very Brief History‚Äù By: Imran Khan Psychedelics are firmly back in the mainstream. Scientists are researching them, veterans are lobbying for them, Elon Musk is microdosing them - but how did we get here? How did western society encounter psychedelics in the first place, why did they become banned and stigmatized, and what brought them back? And what even counts as a psychedelic anyway? Find out answers to all of this, and more, in a talk from Imran Khan of the UC Berkeley Center for the Science of Psychedelics.

Have you ever wished you could step inside the world of Beats Antique? That is what will happen when Beats Antique, Zoe Jakes and The Experientialists come together for House Of Tarot: an experience of ethereal, dark and bizarre storytelling and ritual theater.. You will enter a world where there is no stage and you are in the show, discovering yourself through a series of riddles, trials and tribulations. Meander through the depths of the historic San Francisco Mint along with Zoe Jakes and the House Of Tarot cast to uncover your personal destiny. For those who dare to complete the journey, you will be greeted with a debaucherous celebration of music, dance and performance featuring Zoe Jakes, the House Of Tarot cast, and a full stage performance by Beats Antique at surprise moments throughout the evening. Each room is another adventure as Beats Antique presents their most intimate performance ever. Enter a singular experience with a smaller audience, and explore the unusual beauty of the San Francisco Mint while perhaps brushing shoulders with Beats Antique‚Ä¶ or maybe that was just a trick of the light‚Ä¶You will enter the House Of Tarot experience at a select time slot for your intimate initiation ceremony (maximum 30 people per entrance). After the ceremony you are free to roam The Mint to discover your destiny and learn the mysteries of the House Of Tarot. Entrances are split into Group 1 and Group 2. If you need to enter at a different hour from the rest of your party you can join them for the remainder of your experience so long as your tickets are part of the same group.

Having my first solo show, ‚ÄúPolarities Make Me Whole,‚Äù this Saturday September 21 at Adobe Books. Am excited and nervous to share everything I‚Äôve been working on. The show will exhibit everything from new paintings to drawings from the last 10 years, as well as textiles, photography, and writing. My intention is to share the multitude of ways in which I exist and express myself and how they intersect and contradict one another. It feels terrifying yet honest and I still don‚Äôt know what it‚Äôll look like but am excited to see what comes out of it.

For so long, I waited for there to be a Bart-Caltrain connection in the south...like so long. Now that is sorta possible, if you squint! I've been wanting to take my maiden voyage on a round the bay transit. And now we're doing it! To celebrate the electrification of Caltrain this weekend we follow rail (and a tiny little bus trip) in a full circle around the-part-of-The-Bay-that-I-think-exists, there isn't anything north of the Bay Bridge is there?

Have you ever wished you could step inside the world of Beats Antique? That is what will happen when Beats Antique, Zoe Jakes and The Experientialists come together for House Of Tarot: an experience of ethereal, dark and bizarre storytelling and ritual theater.. You will enter a world where there is no stage and you are in the show, discovering yourself through a series of riddles, trials and tribulations. Meander through the depths of the historic San Francisco Mint along with Zoe Jakes and the House Of Tarot cast to uncover your personal destiny. For those who dare to complete the journey, you will be greeted with a debaucherous celebration of music, dance and performance featuring Zoe Jakes, the House Of Tarot cast, and a full stage performance by Beats Antique at surprise moments throughout the evening. Each room is another adventure as Beats Antique presents their most intimate performance ever. Enter a singular experience with a smaller audience, and explore the unusual beauty of the San Francisco Mint while perhaps brushing shoulders with Beats Antique‚Ä¶ or maybe that was just a trick of the light‚Ä¶You will enter the House Of Tarot experience at a select time slot for your intimate initiation ceremony (maximum 30 people per entrance). After the ceremony you are free to roam The Mint to discover your destiny and learn the mysteries of the House Of Tarot. Entrances are split into Group 1 and Group 2. If you need to enter at a different hour from the rest of your party you can join them for the remainder of your experience so long as your tickets are part of the same group.

Greek desserts and wine will also be available for purchase, and vendors will be on hand selling a selection of items. Traditional dance performances by award-winning folk dance groups will grace the festival, and new and classic Greek music for all to enjoy!

column8: When gentrification uproots your community, how do you navigate it? San Francisco collective Family Not A Group goes beyond just music. From throwing sold-out parties, to tackling inequality via their web series ‚ÄúRent Check‚Äù and educating students by day ‚Äî the collective shares a passion for culture and advocacy. When gentrification uproots your community, how do you navigate it? San Francisco collective Family Not A Group goes beyond just music. From throwing sold-out parties, to tackling inequality via their web series ‚ÄúRent Check‚Äù and educating students by day ‚Äî the collective shares a passion for culture and advocacy.

San Francisco-based artist Annie Albagli considers the origins of life in a new, multifaceted installation work at 500 Capp Street. Albagli transforms the dining room of the David Ireland House into a meditation on where we come from. A carved limestone sculpture covering the entirety of the dining table reaches back in time and into the fossil record to trace the web of life between sea, land, and cosmos. An expansive ceiling work of digital prints layers celestial bodies and mothers‚Äô bodies in a densely intertwined mosaic of birth mythologies. A video work weaves in Albagli‚Äôs personal origin story, and visitors will be able to add their own stories to the installation, sending them via a fax machine stationed in the kitchen.

DanceHack is an annual gathering of creatives, technologists, and dancers to explore the dynamic interplay of dance and technology. This year‚Äôs theme, A Body of Work, invites us to reconnect with the human body‚Äîits innate technology, physicality, and creativity‚Äîin the face of rapid technological advancements. As we delve into advanced tools like motion capture, physiological data sensors, robotics, and AI, we encourage participants to engage with these innovations in ways that enhance our connection to movement.What does it mean to be a dancing body in a world in a world of constant change? How can we cultivate practices that fuse dance and technology, empowering rather than overwhelming? In an era of constant innovation, can we move forward with a focus on harmony? Join us for 3 days of hands-on workshops, serendipitous connections and collaborations ‚Äî let's hack, move, play, and uncover new ways in which dance and technology converge!

column2: The Dark Side of The Migraine
column7: Xenoform Labs, 3338 23rd Street, Apt B San Francisco,, CA 94110
column8: In this wrap-up presentation, Josh will share what he learned about Migraine through his residency. He will share a collection of audio/visual artifacts that he uncovered through research. He will attempt to offer an end-to-end explanation of the mechanics of Migraine in under a minute using visual aids. And he will answer one of the more potent question that came up in the first session ‚Äî ‚Äúhow bad is Migraine actually for your brain?" It turns out the same process underlying Migraine also underlies Traumatic Brain Injury. By understanding the way that these two conditions are related, you can better understand the damage Migraine can do, which can be strong inspiration to take extra steps to avoid it. Josh will wrap up with a summary of his future plans for the Seeing Migraine project.The artist talk and converstaion begins at 8pm

column7: The LAb 2948 16th St, San Francisco, CA, 94103
column8: From their 2001 founding to the duo‚Äôs final shows (and subsequent hiatus) in 2008, Gabriel Mindel Saloman and Pete Swanson aka Yellow Swans carved an influential path through America‚Äôs experimental music underground, at the axis of noise, psychedelia, industrial, drone, and hardcore. During that time they released well over 50 recordings documenting studio experiments, live improvisations, and numerous collaborations. Together they relentlessly toured North America, Europe, and Oceania, performing at numerous international music festivals including Sonar (ES), Open Circuit (BE), and Sonic Protest (FR), and were invited to join Art Council England‚Äôs Free Noise Tour in 2007. After a 15 year break, they have returned to recording and performing. Their music continues to be restless, ragged, and forever in flux, untethered and unresolved.

Whiskerman is a rock-and-roll overture to our great unraveling.Over the last 7 years the Oakland band has developed an underground reputation for tackling the sublime with their ambitious songwriting, thunderous stage show, and acute lyricism. They have since emerged as an engine of the Bay Area‚Äôs revitalized psychedelic and festival scenes. Frontman Graham Patzner, who will crow like a medicine show preacher, and then coo you into the arms of his lovesick eternity, might be a spitfire protege of the underworld himself, though, through and through he will remind you that there is no rapture without artistry. On the surface this is splendid rock-and-roll, rooted in the classic, psych and glam rock tradition, but the pageantry and chaos of Whiskerman‚Äôs performances will leave you describing an experience more than a sound.

column2: Sensual Tantra- a Somatic Approach to Intimacy
column7: The Center SF - 548 Fillmore St @ Oak
column8: Looking to deepen your connection with yourself and others? Join San Francisco‚Äôs foremost Tantra teachers, Erwan & Alicia Davon at the beautiful Center SF for an exquisite evening workshop! Sensual Tantra is a down-to-earth, playful workshop that blends somatic (body) awareness with the ancient practices of Tantra to help you experience intimacy in a whole new way! Perfect for singles to meet like-minded singles and for couples to deepen their connection with each other, this workshop is all about getting out of your head and into your body‚Äîno fluff, just real tools to enhance your relationships and your personal sense of connection. Expect a relaxed, welcoming space where you can explore how breath, movement, and mindful touch can open the door to deeper intimacy. Whether you‚Äôre here solo or with a partner, you‚Äôll learn how to tap into the wisdom of your body and bring more presence and pleasure into your life!

column7: Dogpatch Hub 1278 Minnesota St, San Francisco, CA 94107
column8: How does climate disaster affect our sense of belonging? What is climate in the arts right now? BURNING WILD is an original performance that combines song, movement, audio design, text, documentary video and more to explore a collaged docu-myth about the land, displacement, trauma, and renewal. Created in response to the California wildfires of 2020, it originally began as a community gathering circle to support Northern Californians affected by the wildfires. Recent 2020 fire survivors themselves, Deb√≥rah and Noor draw from their lived experience using personal stories of their relationship to home and placemaking from the Middle East to the Bay Area. In a time when a prolonged megafire season is an annual occurrence, Burning Wild offers an opportunity for resilience, hope and community healing. This is done by returning agency back to the audience and blurring performance distinctions such as dance, theater, audio design and song with social justice and cultural advocacy. BURNING WILD was selected to work in a week-long residency at the prestigious Summer Residency Lab, The Ground Floor: Berkeley Rep‚Äôs Center for the Creation and Development of New Work which brings artists to Berkeley to work on projects in 1‚Äì4 week residencies. All residency artists went through rigorous covid-testing and only worked outside. Creations include sculptures from burnt ephemera, poetry, dance and a site-specific ritual rounded out a week marked by the 1-year anniversary of the Walbridge Fire in Sonoma Co. https://www.avivaarts.org/burning-wild Burning Wild is both an indoor and outdoor experience. Please dress accordingly and wear comfortable walking shoes. If you have any mobility concerns, please let us know. Plan to spend 90-120 minutes with us. Please arrive at Dogpatch Hub at least 15 minutes early to check in and setup the audio experience on your phone. Dogpatch Hub has WiFi and restrooms available. The show will begin and end from here.From the Hub, you will be guided on a very short walk to Progress Park, where the audio drama and live performances will continue. This is a small-group, participatory experience and you may be invited to engage with others.

column2: Emotional Ergonomics: The Age of Cyberphysicality
column7: The Office of Ordinary Things (3647 23rd St
column8: What if the user experiences and interfaces we design should go beyond the 2 and 3 dimensional (such as screens and hardware) to include the dimension of time? What new feelings exist in the physics of cyberphysical? Join us for an emotionally ergonomic evening where we field trip through cyberspace (and meatspace!) to explore how our products and services make us feel, and workshop the new design methods and patterns that might shape our embodied technologies of the future.

Join us at Uzay Gallery for Softly, Sincerely ‚Äì an evening of art and music, featuring emerging artist, Nic Elisa Hampton (@nichampton). Selected works and wearables will be on display and available for purchase, along with a performance and artist talk. ‚ÄúArt allows me to alchemize my anxiety and grief into something that is beautiful and healing. Through my work I emphasize the power of vulnerability, and strength in gentleness. An important component of my painting process is to assume the pose of the figure that I am painting. Allowing myself to internalize the emotions, projecting them through my body and then out onto the surface through color and line. When I create is when I feel most alive, in every sense ‚Äì during studio sessions I may have moments of immense joy, heartache, or anxiety. I hold space for myself to cry, dance, play, laugh‚Ä¶ I hope to gift that to others through my art ‚Äì a safe space to feel the all emotions that demand to be felt.‚Äù

Makeshift Memorials, Small Revolutions is a two-part exhibition, concurrently taking place in Houston at the Blaffer Art Museum and at KADIST San Francisco, which traces the cyclical nature of improvised, responsive, and sustained systems of mutual aid, information sharing, and embodied knowledge sets, as well as their intersectional, intimate, and enduring effects in the wake of the COVID-19 global pandemic. The exhibition includes public programs that examine time, ritual, memory keeping, and community-building practices between 2020 and 2024. The exhibition considers artists as prognosticators‚Äîforecasters of cultural shifts‚Äî and traces evolving artist practices and approaches as informed by activism‚Äîin particular, the creation of mutual aid networks spurred by lived experiences such as the ongoing HIV/AIDS epidemic, as well as the systemic inequities producing Black and Brown grief and the struggle towards liberation. The artists assume the role of narrators for mimetic memory, muffled silences, and informal archiving practices against power structures sanctioning conditions of personal isolation, cultural amnesia, and planetary extinction.

column2: StoryBody: Workshop of the Six Viewpoints
column8: How do you show up? How do you take up space?This November, join Aviva Arts Artistic Director Deb√≥rah Eliezer live in person at the Joe Goode Annex for a 3-Day Viewpoints Intensive.Friday Nov 1st, 6-8pm Saturday Nov 2nd 10:30-1:30pm Sunday Nov 3rd 10:30-1:30pm Using the improvisation vocabulary called the ‚ÄúViewpoints‚Äù as a portal to discover greater authenticity and self-confidence, this workshop will create a safe and supportive space for you to bravely take risks. Through ensemble theater exercises, journaling, improvisational singing, and composition tasks, we‚Äôll rewire neural pathways to overcome self-imposed barriers about sharing who we are and the amount of space we take up.No experience is necessary, and all experience levels are welcome and encouraged. Please note this is a movement experience for all bodies. Please let us know your access needs when you register. Bring a water bottle, a snack, and dress comfortably.

Palladium is a site-specific, durational dance piece converging movement, art, and technology. The ODC Annex building will be transformed into an immersive environment with interactive video and dance performances, time-warping projections, live soundscapes, and AI-generated scores. This new work invites the audience to curate their own experience. The title references both a valuable metal and a sacred statue of Athena, believed to offer protection and prosperity to its possessor. We ask: Does AI benefit everyone or only those in control? Join us for a playful and thought-provoking journey that encourages reflection on how AI impacts society and self.
